content: The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission with specific purposes, composition, duties, powers, and staff provisions. It also includes sections on compensation, security clearances, reports, and termination. The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel, known as the "Commission," is established by the National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009. The Commission aims to evaluate potential improvements in the US approach to high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel management if the Yucca Mountain repository is not operational. It will submit a report to Congress with findings and recommendations to enhance the country's waste management strategies. The United States approach to managing defense waste, spent nuclear fuel, high-level waste, and commercial radioactive waste is being evaluated for potential improvements, especially if the Yucca Mountain repository is not operational. The Commission will provide findings and recommendations to Congress to enhance the country's waste management strategies. The Commission will provide findings and recommendations to Congress to enhance the country's waste management strategies. SEC. 4. COMPOSITION. The Commission, composed of 9 members, will have appointments made by various leaders in consultation with appropriate committees of the Senate and House of Representatives. The Commission, consisting of 9 members, will have appointments made by leaders in consultation with appropriate committees of the Senate and House of Representatives. Appointments include 2 by the minority leader of the House, 1 jointly by the majority leader of the Senate and the Speaker of the House, with qualifications prohibiting engagement in high-level radioactive waste activities under contract with the Department of Energy. The Commission, with 9 members appointed by leaders in consultation with Senate and House committees, must consist of individuals who are prominent US citizens with expertise in engineering, relevant sciences, energy, government, environmental policy, law, and public service. The Commission, comprised of 9 members appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, will be chaired by the individual appointed under subsection (a)(5). The Commission will commence operations promptly after the Act's enactment and will meet as called by the Chairperson. The Commission will meet on the call of the Chairperson or a majority of members, with a quorum of five members. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission is tasked with evaluating alternatives to the Federal Government's spent fuel and high-level waste strategies, including transferring responsibility to a Government corporation. The Commission is evaluating alternatives for managing high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel, including funding, cost-sharing options, centralized storage facilities, and research and development. The Commission is evaluating alternatives for managing high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel, including research and development of advanced fuel cycle technologies and transferring title of spent and future nuclear fuel inventories to the Department of Energy. The Commission is evaluating alternatives for managing high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel, including transferring spent nuclear fuel inventories to at-reactor dry casks and deep geologic disposal for civilian use. The Commission is evaluating alternatives for managing high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel, including deep geologic disposal for civilian and defense wastes, interim strategies for defense wastes, and additional management and technological approaches. The Commission will submit recommendations on existing fees charged to nuclear energy ratepayers and analyze the financial impacts on the Federal Government's contractual liability under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982. The Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982 requires the Commission to submit a final report to Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, and administer oaths. It can also enter into contracts to fulfill its duties and obtain information from federal agencies. The Federal Government entities must provide information, suggestions, estimates, and statistics to the Commission as requested. The Commission and its staff must handle information in accordance with the law. The General Services Administration will provide administrative support to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission may receive assistance from other departments and agencies of the Federal Government, including services, funds, facilities, staff, and support services as authorized by law. The Commission is also allowed to use the United States mails like other government entities. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission. Staff provisions are also included. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint staff members and set their compensation without following certain regulations of the United States Code. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint staff members and set their compensation within specified limits. Staff members are considered federal employees under certain sections of the United States Code, except for members of the Commission. The Commission can detail Federal Government employees without reimbursement, and detailees retain their rights and privileges. The Commission can also procure consultant services at specified rates. SEC. 9. COMPENSATION; TRAVEL EXPENSES. Each member of the Commission may receive compensation not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for a position at level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are also entitled to travel expenses while performing duties for the Commission. Persons employed intermittently in the Government service can claim expenses under section 5703(b) of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 10. SECURITY CLEARANCES. The Federal agencies will cooperate with the Commission to provide security clearances to members and staff. No access to classified information will be granted without appropriate clearances. SEC. 11. REPORTS. The Commission will release an interim report for public comment within a year of the Act's enactment, followed by a final report to Congress within two years of the first meeting. The final report will include findings, conclusions, recommendations, and opinions agreed upon by the majority of Commission members. The final report will contain opinions of Commission members who disagree with any item, along with explanations and alternative recommendations. Public comments will also be considered. SEC. 12. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out the Act. Such sums as necessary are authorized to remain available until expended. SEC. 13. Termination of the Commission's authority 180 days after the final report submission. During this period, the Commission may conclude its activities, provide testimony to Congress, and disseminate the final report.
